trans-unit.source: Intermediate Artist Programmer
trans-unit.target: Intermediate Artist Programmer

trans-unit.source: This walkthrough shows how you can create custom extensions for the particle system, providing functionality not available in the core engine.
trans-unit.target: This walkthrough shows how you can create custom extensions for the particle system, providing functionality not available in the core engine.

trans-unit.source: If you're not familiar with editing particles, see Create particles.
trans-unit.target: If you're not familiar with editing particles, see Create particles.

trans-unit.source: Start by creating a new Sample: Particles project.
trans-unit.target: Start by creating a new Sample: Particles project.

trans-unit.source: Particles sample project
trans-unit.target: Particles sample project

trans-unit.source: This project contains different scenes that demonstrate different ways to use particles. Open the CustomParticles scene.
trans-unit.target: This project contains different scenes that demonstrate different ways to use particles. Open the CustomParticles scene.

trans-unit.source: There are three particle entities in the scene: ConeEmitter15, ConeEmitter30, and ConeEmitter45.
trans-unit.target: There are three particle entities in the scene: ConeEmitter15, ConeEmitter30, and ConeEmitter45.

trans-unit.source: Select one of the particle entities. In the Property Grid, navigate to its source particle system and expand the emitter.
trans-unit.target: Select one of the particle entities. In the Property Grid, navigate to its source particle system and expand the emitter.

trans-unit.source: media/particles-samples-custom-1.png
trans-unit.target: media/particles-samples-custom-1.png

trans-unit.source: There are four custom elements in this emitter:
trans-unit.target: There are four custom elements in this emitter:

trans-unit.source: The custom spawner is similar to the spawn-per-second spawner, but also emits a burst of particles every time it loops.
trans-unit.target: The custom spawner is similar to the spawn-per-second spawner, but also emits a burst of particles every time it loops.

trans-unit.source: The custom initializer initially positions the particles in a cone shape and sets their velocity accordingly.
trans-unit.target: The custom initializer initially positions the particles in a cone shape and sets their velocity accordingly.

trans-unit.source: The custom updater operates on a new particle field named RactangleXY, allowing the shape builder to use non-uniform sizes when building the billboards.
trans-unit.target: The custom updater operates on a new particle field named RactangleXY, allowing the shape builder to use non-uniform sizes when building the billboards.

trans-unit.source: The custom shape builder is similar to the billboard with two additions. It can create non-uniform rectangles, rather than the standard squares, and it can align (fix) the rectangle's Y axis to the world's Y axis rather than the camera space.
trans-unit.target: The custom shape builder is similar to the billboard with two additions. It can create non-uniform rectangles, rather than the standard squares, and it can align (fix) the rectangle's Y axis to the world's Y axis rather than the camera space.

trans-unit.source: Spawner
trans-unit.target: Spawner

trans-unit.source: We'll create a spawner which emits particles per second and in bursts every few seconds. We could do this by adding two different spawners, but for this sample we'll combine them.
trans-unit.target: We'll create a spawner which emits particles per second and in bursts every few seconds. We could do this by adding two different spawners, but for this sample we'll combine them.

trans-unit.source: This class mimics the @'Stride.Particles.Spawners.ParticleSpawner', with the addition of a BurstCount and a burstTimer to control how often and how many particles are spawned in bursts.
trans-unit.target: This class mimics the @'Stride.Particles.Spawners.ParticleSpawner', with the addition of a BurstCount and a burstTimer to control how often and how many particles are spawned in bursts.

trans-unit.source: The SpawnNew method is called every frame to allow the spawner to calculate how many new particles should be emitted in the emitter based on the elapsed time.
trans-unit.target: The SpawnNew method is called every frame to allow the spawner to calculate how many new particles should be emitted in the emitter based on the elapsed time.

trans-unit.source: As an exercise, try implementing the following changes:
trans-unit.target: As an exercise, try implementing the following changes:

trans-unit.source: Rather than one-second bursts, create a property and have the user control the timing.
trans-unit.target: Rather than one-second bursts, create a property and have the user control the timing.

trans-unit.source: Remove the spawn-per-second fields and make it a pure burst spawner.
trans-unit.target: Remove the spawn-per-second fields and make it a pure burst spawner.

trans-unit.source: Our spawner only emits particles, but doesn't set any fields. This is done by the initializer.
trans-unit.target: Our spawner only emits particles, but doesn't set any fields. This is done by the initializer.

trans-unit.source: Initializer
trans-unit.target: Initializer

trans-unit.source: We want to place the particles in a cone and shoot them outwards when they spawn.
trans-unit.target: We want to place the particles in a cone and shoot them outwards when they spawn.

trans-unit.source: Our initializer simply defines an angle for the cone and strength for the velocity. Any scaling and rotation of the cone come from the location inheritance and offset, which are common for all initializers and updaters and are ready to use. For more information, see the @'Stride.Particles.Initializers.ParticleInitializer'.
trans-unit.target: Our initializer simply defines an angle for the cone and strength for the velocity. Any scaling and rotation of the cone come from the location inheritance and offset, which are common for all initializers and updaters and are ready to use. For more information, see the @'Stride.Particles.Initializers.ParticleInitializer'.

trans-unit.source: The constructor for the initializer is important, as it sets the list of required fields we'll use. The initializer sets the particle's position and velocity, so we add those, and needs to generate some randomness, so we also add the random seed which we are going to use. All particles have Life and RandomSeed fields when they spawn.
trans-unit.target: The constructor for the initializer is important, as it sets the list of required fields we'll use. The initializer sets the particle's position and velocity, so we add those, and needs to generate some randomness, so we also add the random seed which we are going to use. All particles have Life and RandomSeed fields when they spawn.

trans-unit.source: Updater
trans-unit.target: Updater

trans-unit.source: We want our updater to change a particle's width and height every frame based on a simple sine function over the particle's life.
trans-unit.target: We want our updater to change a particle's width and height every frame based on a simple sine function over the particle's life.

trans-unit.source: Because there's no such field yet, start by creating a new particle field. Let's name it RactangleXY:
trans-unit.target: Because there's no such field yet, start by creating a new particle field. Let's name it RactangleXY:

trans-unit.source: The field has type @'Stride.Core.Mathematics.Vector2', since we only need two values for the width and the height. No fields are added automatically to the particles, so even if you have many declarations, the particle size won't change. Fields are only added when we plug a module which requires them, such as the custom updater below.
trans-unit.target: The field has type @'Stride.Core.Mathematics.Vector2', since we only need two values for the width and the height. No fields are added automatically to the particles, so even if you have many declarations, the particle size won't change. Fields are only added when we plug a module which requires them, such as the custom updater below.

trans-unit.source: For API reference, see @'Stride.Particles.Modules.ParticleUpdater'.
trans-unit.target: For API reference, see @'Stride.Particles.Modules.ParticleUpdater'.

trans-unit.source: Let's take a look at the Update method. The sample code is longer, but here we've trimmed it for the sake of simplicity.
trans-unit.target: Let's take a look at the Update method. The sample code is longer, but here we've trimmed it for the sake of simplicity.

trans-unit.source: The updater will animate all particles' RectangleXY fields with a simple sine and cosine functions over their life.
trans-unit.target: The updater will animate all particles' RectangleXY fields with a simple sine and cosine functions over their life.

trans-unit.source: Shape builder
trans-unit.target: Shape builder

trans-unit.source: The shape builder is the class which takes all particle fields and creates the actual shape we are going to render. It's a little long, so let's break it down.
trans-unit.target: The shape builder is the class which takes all particle fields and creates the actual shape we are going to render. It's a little long, so let's break it down.

trans-unit.source: public override int QuadsPerParticle { get; protected set; } = 1;
trans-unit.target: public override int QuadsPerParticle { get; protected set; } = 1;

trans-unit.source: The engine draws quads using 1 quad = 4 vertices = 6 indices, but we can only specify the number of quads we need. For a rectangle we need only one.
trans-unit.target: The engine draws quads using 1 quad = 4 vertices = 6 indices, but we can only specify the number of quads we need. For a rectangle we need only one.

trans-unit.source: !Note The number of quads is important because the vertex buffer is allocated and mapped prior to writing out the vertex data. If we allocate smaller buffer it might result in illegal memory access and corruption.
trans-unit.target: !Note The number of quads is important because the vertex buffer is allocated and mapped prior to writing out the vertex data. If we allocate smaller buffer it might result in illegal memory access and corruption.

trans-unit.source: public unsafe override int BuildVertexBuffer(ParticleVertexBuilder vtxBuilder, Vector3 inverseViewX, Vector3 inverseViewY, ref Vector3 spaceTranslation, ref Quaternion spaceRotation, float spaceScale, ParticleSorter sorter)
trans-unit.target: public unsafe override int BuildVertexBuffer(ParticleVertexBuilder vtxBuilder, Vector3 inverseViewX, Vector3 inverseViewY, ref Vector3 spaceTranslation, ref Quaternion spaceRotation, float spaceScale, ParticleSorter sorter)

trans-unit.source: This method is called when it needs our shape builder to iterate over all particles and build the shape. The @'Stride.Particles.VertexLayouts.ParticleVertexBuilder' is the wrapper around our vertex stream. We'll use it to write out the vertex data for the particles.
trans-unit.target: This method is called when it needs our shape builder to iterate over all particles and build the shape. The @'Stride.Particles.VertexLayouts.ParticleVertexBuilder' is the wrapper around our vertex stream. We'll use it to write out the vertex data for the particles.

trans-unit.source: inverseViewX and inverseViewY are unit vectors in camera space passed down to the shape builder if we need to generate camera-facing shapes.
trans-unit.target: inverseViewX and inverseViewY are unit vectors in camera space passed down to the shape builder if we need to generate camera-facing shapes.

trans-unit.source: Our particles' width and height depend both on the uniform size field Size and the field we created earlier in this walkthrough, RectangleXY. From there, we need to set the positions and texture coordinates for the four corner vertices of our quad. The number of vertices we have to set is per particle four times the number of quads we requested.
trans-unit.target: Our particles' width and height depend both on the uniform size field Size and the field we created earlier in this walkthrough, RectangleXY. From there, we need to set the positions and texture coordinates for the four corner vertices of our quad. The number of vertices we have to set is per particle four times the number of quads we requested.

trans-unit.source: Conclusion
trans-unit.target: Conclusion

trans-unit.source: With these 4 custom modules you can add a lot of functionality to the particle engine and tailor behavior to your needs. Because they're all serialized and loaded in Game Studio, once you create them, you can use them directly from Game Studio, together with the core modules.
trans-unit.target: With these 4 custom modules you can add a lot of functionality to the particle engine and tailor behavior to your needs. Because they're all serialized and loaded in Game Studio, once you create them, you can use them directly from Game Studio, together with the core modules.

trans-unit.source: If you want to experiment with the modules, try adding a new .cs file to the CustomParticles.Game project. You can duplicate one of the existing classes, but don't forget to change the class name and the data contract to avoid collisions.
trans-unit.target: If you want to experiment with the modules, try adding a new .cs file to the CustomParticles.Game project. You can duplicate one of the existing classes, but don't forget to change the class name and the data contract to avoid collisions.

trans-unit.source: You can then reload the scripts in Game Studio. If they don't load, relaunch your project. If there are no compilation errors in your code you should see the new modules in the spawners, initializers, updaters and shape builders lists.
trans-unit.target: You can then reload the scripts in Game Studio. If they don't load, relaunch your project. If there are no compilation errors in your code you should see the new modules in the spawners, initializers, updaters and shape builders lists.
